üéØ Key Takeaways for quick navigation:

00:00 üè¶ Banking history spans back to ancient times, with evidence of banking activities in Mesopotamia, Rome, and beyond, highlighting sophisticated financial systems.
03:29 ü™ô The gold standard was a monetary system where currencies were linked to fixed quantities of gold, but it had limitations, including inflexibility during economic crises.
08:03 üí∞ Fractional Reserve banking allows banks to hold only a fraction of customer deposits in reserve, stimulating economic growth by facilitating lending and investments.
09:21 üìà Advantages of Fractional Reserve banking include economic growth, profitability, and financial intermediation.
10:29 üèÉ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è Disadvantages include vulnerability to bank runs, inflation risk, and encouraging excessive risk-taking.
12:07 üè¶ Retail banks serve individuals and small businesses, offering services like savings accounts, loans, and credit cards.
14:23 üè¢ Commercial banks primarily support businesses, providing business loans, trade finance, and treasury management services.
15:19 üíº Investment banks specialize in capital markets, handling mergers and acquisitions, underwriting, asset management, and trading.
16:42 üèõÔ∏è Central banks oversee a nation's money supply, monetary policy, and act as lenders of last resort during financial crises. They also supervise and regulate the banking sector.
18:53 üåê The future of banking remains a topic of discussion, with various opinions on how it will evolve in the coming years.

Ratio:
{
(Debt=1)<(2=Loan)
((Total Debt(20 Year))=(Payout(20 Year)))=500B
Premium=(Payout*10%)=10%
(Loan>Premium)=Surplus
}

Premium=Payout(20 Year)*10%=10%
Premium=500B*10%=10%
Premium=50B=10%
Cash=Loan-Premium
Cash=120B-50B

Premium=40B=10%
Payout(20 Year)=Premium/10%=100%
Payout(20 Year)=40B/10%=100%
Payout(20 Year)=400B=100%=income.

Balance=Cash-Premium
Balance=70B-40B
Balance=30B

I don't know if anything in this video is surprising or unintended.
First, banking in general like most of their customers and all businesses in general rely on predictable business conditions to make money. The rise in interest rates have caught many financial institutions by surprise after a couple decades of near zero interest rates so higher interest rates are likely the first time this has been experienced in the career of most financiers and financial analysts. But the disappearance of profits and even losses should be temporary, well managed banks and other financial institutions should adjust and gradually a new state of equilibrium will be reached for financial instruments.

As for customers, this is likely the intended effect the Federal Reserve is trying to achieve. The Fed is tasked with fighting inflation and a big part of this is to discourage the American Consumer from being so willing to pay ever higher spiraling prices for goods and services, and for businesses to be so willing to borrow to support making that last incremental widget that can still be made profitably.

This is all natural, including any banking losses, likely due to financial practices that were based on expectations of a stable economy with lower interest rates.

You are absolutely correct about both banks and credit unions. I was a federal bank examiner for 18.5 years, followed by 10.5 years as a financial and statistical analyst for the same federal financial institution regulator. Many banks, large and small, defer and "time" provision for loan loss. They can play games with economic factors used to adjust the loss factors within any segment of the loan portfolio, overestimate the net realizable value of collateral (for large, "non homogeneous" loans), and/or over fund the Allowance for Loan Losses in good times and take advantage of over funding to "smooth out" the losses during lean times. Thus, losses are not necessarily recognized in the period when actually incurred.

ZIRP (Zero interest rate policy) and in some cases, NIRP (Negative interest rate policy) have contributed to bank fixed income portfolio growth as duration and market risk were kept in the freezer compartment for a very long time. Hence, banks' risk management desks were not prioritizing too many action plans about IRR interest rate risk management as the policy rate/s were kept on hold!
Now, once you have the risk in the policy rate, that led to multiple market and liquidity risks, which created a classic ALRM Asset Liability Risk Management Event!
SVB and other banks are prime examples of Risk Management Desk failure and for once we can blame the treasury or other departments of these banks.
Most noticeable was that SVB was operating w/o a CRO Chief Risk Officer for many months, which goes on to show that financial institutions are scared of bolstering internal controls and the three risk lines of defence beyond certain protocol levels?
CS Debacle was also an archetypical financial risk management failure!
We can write an entire book on Governance, Compliance and Auditing book of malpractices in light of how Switzerland's top bank and how its Risk Department and silos failed to anticipate emerging risks and/or reduce financial losses when they materialised.
I think banks need to go beyond basic Basel Accords and develop forward-looking ERM programs and model frameworks so that all lines of defence can work in coordination during a crisis.
Of course, Crisis management and Risk Management are not the same disciplines!
Add Complexity Management to it, and it becomes a totally new area of study in Financial Studies and Systemic Risk Regulation.

Look to the millennial guys who started Airbnb and took over so much affordable housing around the world, or that WeWork guy who took over so much commercial office space. Look also at the private equity funds that continue to buy up housing, and investigate other bad actors. In July 2023, my major US bank froze my account. I have had it for over 40 years. Today is February 9, 2024. I called. I still do not have access. Yes, I have been to the bank and identified myself. Yes, I have the names and emails concerning the two "conceirge" people in the bank who were supposed to either grant me on-line access or send me free cancelled checks. Yes, twice, the same person has had to send me cancelled checks by email with another secret code. I am waiting for the last check to clear, get a copy and bye bank.

The foregoing is not unusual. It is a function of "high tech" and the reduction of "customer service". Following Dan's suggestion, I opened accounts at multiple credit unions and additional banks. The slippage in bank customer service did not start in 2023. About 20 years ago, Bank of America pioneered a new version of customer service. You could no longer call directly to a branch. You had to call a general number. The customer service has further changed to a new business model. You call, get put on hold "due to the high volume of calls" (which is bad grammar copied by companies), finally, you leave a number and maybe you get a call back and maybe not.

Reduce the stress as Dan suggests: 1. keep a pile of cash at home; 2. keep cash in the car; 3. keep a spare credit card in the car on a different account; 4. open multiple accounts at banks and credit unions; 5. keep a copy of each month's statement, preferably in writing.

The one thing that gives me pause on this, is that this type of thing has been said for a long time, (but obviously you will say, ahhh, that's just the perma-bears), but what I am wondering about is, our whole economy has changed in form; it is no longer the retail investor, your average Joe or Jane who are being the greatest influencers of the economy as a whole, I think, based on what I have read (can't claim to have data myself), and maybe we are making calls on which way the economy is headed based on outmoded methods . . . . things have been changing extremely rapidly, AI has took off like a rocket, and the wealthy have been getting wealthier at an extraordinarily high rate . . . . and the old ways of analysis might just be the wrong way to look at this. That and considering that the super-wealthy control far more stocks and actual economy-influencing businesses than all these retail trading debt burdened folks . . . .

The following is from BARD: What is the approximate ratio of stocks controlled by the super-wealthy versus the retail traders?

"Determining the exact ratio of stocks controlled by the super-wealthy versus retail traders is a complex task with no definitive answer. However, we can analyze several factors and estimates to get a general idea:

Concentration of Ownership:

Top 10%: Recent studies and data show that the top 10% of households in the US own around 89% of all publicly traded stocks. This means a very small group holds a vast majority of the wealth tied to the stock market.
Top 1%: Within the top 10%, the top 1% of households are estimated to hold an even larger share, potentially approaching 50% or more.
Retail Traders: The remaining 11% of stocks are held by the bottom 90% of households, which includes retail traders. This number has been declining in recent years, suggesting decreasing access to stock ownership for average individuals."

So who is really controlling this economy? Certainly NOT the retail traders. I think that many analysts are not considering this, and we might find out later that the historic data may be actually hindering us some.

Lena, what you shared would have make sense for the late 1920s when the different economies in the world were not so integrated & few countries are holding on to much lower amount of US Treasury Notes & USD as their National Reserves. The time for occurence of facing such a localized "collapse" if it was to ever happen, tend to be after the 3rd quarter annoucement of earning reports which favors the month of Oct as it did in 1929 when the market tend to be most fixated on the doom & gloom sentiments after repeated disappointing results. But today is 2020s, as much as the rationale for how a textbook example of how a localized economy collapse can playout still applies today, that did not occur over the past century as the global market forces invisible at work here play a much larger role which was unaccounted for. & the reason behind the US FEDs maintaining a high interest rates is not just simply to curb inflation as the localized rationale would perceive it to be, you just need to study the economic figures coming out from the 2nd largest economy China as well to see that there is now a real wrestling for powers & global dominance between USA & China to orientate & influence the flow & direction of investments from the leading global companies & investors sentiments. Unlike the late 1920s, in the highly integrated global economies of 2020s, it is insufficient to analyse with localized data in US economy alone to narrate a collapse when there are many other significant economies apart from the US economy that are coming into the equation.

Why the Bible is 100% the word of the living God. You will find it becoming increasingly difficult for your mind to comprehend what you‚Äôre reading:

Excerpts from Dr. Ivan Panin's 1899 Letter to the New York Sun

The first 17 verses of the New Testament contain the genealogy of the Christ. It consists of two main parts: Verses 1-11 cover the period from Abraham, the father of the chosen people, to the Captivity, when they ceased as an independent people. Verses 12-17 cover the period from the Captivity to the promised Deliverer, the Christ.

Let us examine the first part of this genealogy.

Its vocabulary has 49 words, or 7 x 7. This number is itself seven (Feature 1) sevens (Feature 2), and the sum of its factors is 2 sevens (Feature 3). Of these 49 words 28, or 4 sevens, begin with a vowel; and 21, or 3 sevens, begin with a consonant (Feature 4).

Again: these 49 words of the vocabulary have 266 letters, or 7 x 2 x 19; this number is itself 38 sevens (Feature 5), and the sum of its factors is 28, or 4 sevens (Feature 6, while the sum of its figures is 14, or 2 sevens (Feature 7). Of these 266 letters, moreover, 140, or 20 sevens, are vowels, and 126, or 18 sevens, are consonants (Feature 8).

That is to say: Just as the number of words in the vocabulary is a multiple of seven, so is the number of its letters a multiple of seven; just as the sum of the factors of the number of the words is a multiple of seven, so is the sum of the factors of the number of their letters a multiple of seven. And just as the number of words is divided between vowel words and consonant words by sevens, so is their number of letters divided between vowels and consonants by sevens.

Again: Of these 49 words 35, or 5 sevens, occur more than once in the passage; and 14, or 2 sevens, occur but once (Feature 9); seven occur in more than one form, and 42, or 6 sevens, occur in only one form (Feature 10). And among the parts of speech the 49 words are thus divided: 42, or 6 sevens, are nouns, seven are not nouns (Feature 12). Of the nouns 35 or 5 sevens, are Proper names, seven are common nouns (Feature 12). Of the Proper names 28 are male ancestors of the Christ, and seven are not (Feature 13).

Moreover, these 49 words are distributed alphabetically thus: Words under A-E are 21 in number, or 3 sevens; Z-K 14, or 2 sevens; M-X also 14. No other groups of sevens stopping at the end of a letter are made by these 49 words, the groups of sevens stop with these letters and no others. But the letters A, E, Z, K, M, X, are letters 1, 5, 6, 10, 12, 22, of the Greek alphabet, and the sum of these numbers (called their Place Values) is 56, or 8 sevens (Feature 14).

‚Ä¶
‚Ä¶ The New Testament is written in Greek. The Greeks had no separate symbols for expressing numbers, corresponding to our Arabic figures, but used instead the letters of their alphabet: just as the Hebrews, in whose language the Old Testament is written, made use for the same purpose of theirs. Accordingly, the 24 Greek letters stand for the following numbers: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 7, 8, 9, 10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 60, 70, 80, 100, 200, 300, 400, 500, 600, 700, 800. Every Greek word is thus a sum in arithmetic obtained by adding the numbers for which its letters stand, or their numeric values. Now the vocabulary to the entire genealogy has 72 words. If we write its numeric value over each of these 72 words, and add them, we get for their sum 42,364, or 6,052 sevens, distributed into the following alphabetical groups only: A-B, have 9,821, or 1,403 sevens: G-D, 1,904, or 272 sevens; 3,703, or 529 sevens; TH-R, 19,264, or 2,752 sevens; A-X 7,672, or 1,096 sevens. But the numeric value of the 10 letters used for making these groups is 931, or 7 x 7 x 19, a multiple not only of seven but of seven sevens.

‚Ä¶ The second part of this chapter, verses 18-25, relates the birth of the Christ. It consists of 161 words, or 23 sevens; occurring in 105 forms, or 15 sevens, with a vocabulary of 77 words or 11 sevens. Joseph is spoken to here by an angel. Accordingly, of the 77 words the angel uses 28 or 4 sevens; of the 105 forms he uses 35 or 5 sevens; the numeric value of the vocabulary is 52,605 or 7,515 sevens; of the forms, 65,429 or 9,347 sevens. This enumeration only begins as it were barely to scratch the surface of the numerics of this passage. But what is specially noteworthy here is the fact that the angel‚Äôs speech has also a scheme of sevens making it a kind of ring within a ring, a wheel within a wheel. If Mr. L. can write a similar passage of 161 words with the same scheme of sevens alone (though there are several others here) in some three years, he would have accomplished a still greater wonder. Let us assume that Matthew accomplished this feat in only 6 months.
3. The second chapter of Matthew tells of the childhood of the Christ. Its vocabulary has 161 words, or 23 sevens, with 896 letters, or 128 sevens, and 238 forms, or 34 sevens; the numeric value of the vocabulary is 123,529 or 17, 647 sevens; of the forms, 166,985 or 23, 885 sevens; and so on through pages of enumeration. This chapter has at least four logical divisions, and each division shows alone the same phenomena found in the chapter as a whole. Thus the first six verses have a vocabulary of 56 words, or 8 sevens, etc. There are some speeches here: Herod speaks, the Magi speak, the angel speaks. But so pronounced are numeric phenomena here, that though there are as it were numerous rings within rings, and wheels within wheels, each is perfect in itself through forming all the while only part of the rest‚Ä¶

4. There is not, however, a single paragraph of the scores in Matthew that is not constructed in exactly the same manner. Only with each additional paragraph the difficulty of constructing it increases not in arithmatical, but in geometrical progression. For he contrives to write his paragraphs so as to develop constantly fixed numeric relations to what goes before and after. Thus in his last chapter he contrives to use just 7 words not used by him before‚Ä¶

Anyhow, Matthew did it, and we thus have a miracle ‚Äì an unheard-or literary, mathematical artist, unequaled, hardly even conceivable‚Ä¶
A second fact is yet more important: In his very first section, the genealogy discussed above, the words found nowhere else in the New Testament occur 42 times, 7 x 6; and have 126 letters, 7 x 6 x 3, each number a multiple not only of seven, but of 6 sevens, to name only two of the many numeric features of these words. But how did Matthew know, when designing this scheme for these words (whose sole characteristic is that they are found nowhere else in the New Testament) that they would not be found in the other 26 books? That they would not be used by the other 7 New Testament writers? Unless we assume the impossible hypothesis that he had an agreement with them to that effect, he must have had the rest of the New Testament before him when he wrote his book. The Gospel of Matthew, then, was written last.
5. It so happens, however, that the Gospel of Mark shows the very same phenomena. Thus the very passage called so triumphantly in today‚Äôs SUN a ‚Äòforgery,‚Äô the Last Twelve Verses of Mark, presents among some sixty features of sevens the following phenomena: It has 175 words, or 25 sevens, a vocabulary of 98 words, or 2 sevens of sevens, with 553 letters, or 79 sevens; 133 forms, or 19 sevens, and so on to the minutest detail. Mark then, is another miracle, another unparalled literary genius. And in the same way in which it was shown that Matthew wrote last it is also shown that Mark, too, wrote last. Thus to take an example from this very passage: It has just one word found nowhere else in the New Testament, theta, alpha, nu, alpha, sigma, iota, upsilon, omicron, sigma, deadly. This fact is signaled by no less than seven features of sevens, thus: its numeric value is 581 or 83 sevens, with the sum of its figures 14, or 2 sevens, of which the letters 3, 5, 7, 9 from the beginning of the word have 490, or 7 x 7 x 5 x 2: a multiple of seven sevens, with the sum of its factors 21, or 3 sevens. In the vocabulary it is preceded by 42 words: 7 x 6; in the passage itself by 126 words, or 7 x 6 x 3, both numbers multiples not only of seven, but of 6 sevens. We have thus established before us this third fact for Mr. L. to contemplate: Matthew surely wrote after Mark, and Mark just as surely wrote after Matthew.
6. It happens, however, to be a fourth fact that Luke presents the same phenomena as Matthew and Mark, and so does John, and James, and Peter, and Jude, and Paul. And we have thus no longer two great unheard-of mathematical literati, but eight of them and each wrote after the other.
7. And not only this: As Luke and Peter wrote each 2 books, John 5, and Paul 14, it can in the same way be shown that each of the 27 New Testament books was written last. In fact, not a page of the over 500 in Wescott and Hort‚Äôs Greek edition (which the writer has used throughout) but it can be demonstrated thus to have been written last.
The phenomena are there and there is no human way of explaining them. Eight men cannot each write last, 27 books, some 500 pages, cannot each be written last. But lets assume that one Mind directed the whole, and the problem is solved simply enough: by this Verbal Inspiration ‚Äì of every jot and tittle of the New Testament.
There remains only to be added that by precisely the same kind of evidence the Hebrew Old Testament is proved to be equally inspired. This the very first verse of Genesis has seven words, 28 letters, or 4 sevens: to name only two out of the dozens of numeric features of this one verse of only seven words.

Ms. Petrova is making sound observations. I too am a CPA who just retired from my career with the US government. I spent 18.5 years as a capital markets examiner for a federal financial institution regulator (with a capital markets emphasis), then 10.5 years as a financial analyst for the same agency. In addition to her sound observations, please note that the inflation adjusted GDP has already declined for two consecutive quarters- signalling recession. Federal Reserve rate increases, combined with quantitative tightening are the primary causes. As she notes, consumer spending is under pressure. Given approximately 70 percent of our economy is dependent upon consumer spending, further GDP erosion can be expected. Please also remember our government debt to GDP ratio is as high as it was immediately following WW II, but we don't have the growing economy, balanced budgets and favorable balance of trade that permitted us to pay down the debt back then. Another factor to consider is that one third of US government debt will reprice within 12 months at materially higher interest rates. Thus, the US is poorly positioned to provide the massive stimulus necessary to prevent recession.

The problem with the collapse of the economy is a cascading effect. One raises prices, another sees them make profit and thinks they will do the same. Then the process repeats like dominoes and everyone is raising prices thinking they will make more profit. And they do from the short sighted futuristic view. But eventually the effect has grown so large and to many raised prices that then everyone starts to suffer from it. Because then big business starts to lose profit because prices are to high and people cant afford them, with the reason being because prices on everything has risen as well, and then the people don't have enough money left after that for much. So this never works out to the benefit for the people or for business in the long run. The only way to stop this from happening is for everyone to try not to raise prices in the first place to prevent the cascading effect. Or to have laws put in place that state prices can only be raised to some set limit based on current affairs relating to wages earned and what is needed to survive for families at the current time. But I can see it coming as well if nothing is done about it. Far to many are following the thought that if they raise prices they make more profit. But that only has one eventual outcome, that everyone loses in the end.

What is "Rising Interest Rate" ? Powell and the FMOC sets the Fed Funds rate which is over-night between banks. Real interest rate for households and corporate are on the yield curve (plus premium), not set by Powell. They are set by bond auction discovery, driven by inflation and inflation expectation to the maturity date of the bond. So it is the market which sets actual interest rates, not Powell.  Yes, he chooses the mood music but he doesn't control the yield curve.

In particular, JPMorgan‚Äôs downgrade was partially because the bank runs a ‚Äúcomplex‚Äù capital markets business that may post ‚Äúsubstantial‚Äù risks to its creditors.

A potential upgrade for JPMorgan ‚Äúwould depend on sustaining strong and stable performance and capital levels‚Äù above its competitors, Moody‚Äôs says.

Despite the downgrade from Moody‚Äôs, all three banks‚Äô stock prices are in the green for November, so far.

The agency also said that the downgrade of the banks‚Äô ratings was in line with a previous downgrade of U.S. sovereign credit rating, which was also bumped down from stable to negative.

In a research note released last quarter, Moody‚Äôs said that US banks were facing ‚Äúsignificant risk‚Äù of deposit flight due to interest rate and asset-liability management (ALM) risks.

Moody‚Äôs, which controls 80% of the global ratings industry along with Standard & Poors (S&P), is forecasting a recession for the US economy early next year.

‚ÄúWe continue to expect a mild recession in early 2024, and given the funding strains on the US banking sector, there will likely be a tightening of credit conditions and rising loan losses for US banks.‚Äù üòÖüòÖüòÖüòÖüòÖüòÖüòÖüòÖ

Think what it means to hold the asset to maturity.  It means to lose (in base value) at the rate of the small return subtracted from the inflation rate.  So if you were earning 2% and inflation is 5% you are losing 3% (roughly) in base value (buying power) year after year.   Even 3% will cause a divsion of this value by far more than half long before a thirty year bond matures.  You will get your dollars but they will be worth far less.  The strategy would rather be to hold only until you can sell if opportunity affords, that is, if you have a chance due to a falling of interest rates.  (Then repurchase at present rates if they look hopeful.)

It is not just the banks. All the Trreasuries (and other bonds) sold in the era of very low interest rate are sitting in the portofolio of banks, pension funds, HNW individuals, soverign wealth funds ... They sit there collecting very little interest, but mark to cost in stead of marked to market, until they eventual mature and the principal is paid back. What that means is nobody has to recognise a loss, just a low interest (or ROI) for the duration of the bond. Banks are no different. As long as they don't have a bank run and be forced to sell the bonds and recognise the losses, all will be fine.

What is wrong with the CDO losing value because of the degraded credit assets used as collateral by the banks issuing these kind of bonds? It happened many times before and nothing happened but the refinancing of the CDO portfolios through FED repurchase agreements with the commercial banks, in order to reflate the value of the real estate assets portfolio used as collateral for the CDO. The FED simply repurchases the degraded assets on the repo market, in order to solve the liquidity problem of the commercial banks. The central bankers can easily create hundred of billions in liquidities on the repo market every week if needed. It is a routine operation to manage the counterparty risk. There is nothing wrong with that.

#19:30 - No Patrik, the crash of Silvergate was not caused by crypto-related events. I know you hate crypto and millenials living in the moms basements, but please keep to the truth.

Silvergate crashed because of good, old-fashioned greed. Silvergate had, as you said at #14:30 invested a lot of their customers deposits in these hold-to-maturity bonds, these "agency bonds": bonds that mature some 4-5 years into the future.

Investopedia (which I choose to trust on this matter - your mileage may wary) describes these agency bonds as follows:

- "An agency bond is a security issued by a government-sponsored enterprise or by a federal government department other than the U.S. Treasury. Some are not fully guaranteed in the same way that U.S. Treasury and municipal bonds are.
[...]
Treasury bonds are attractive to investors because of their safety, liquidity, and state tax- exempt interest. Agency bonds are attractive to investors because of the safety, liquidity, higher yields relative to Treasuries, and for some agencies, their state tax-exempt interest."

The problem with these hold-to-maturity bonds is that when Silvergate bought them at "fair value" just a few years or months ago, the US interest rate was much lower than today. And bond values correlates inverse to interest rate, so now with the current and continuing FED raises of interests, the value of these fixed interest bonds goes down.

Now, as all of us "knows" you really haven't lost money in the stock market until you sell your bad performing stonks. Same with Silvergate. On their accounting books, these agency bonds was reported and valued at their original price, not their new fair value taking the current interest rate into account. It was only when Silvergate customers started to withdraw deposits and Silvergate needed good old fashioned fiat US Dollars to keep up with the withdrawals, the problem with the original fair value not being fair any longer became a problem. The agency bonds, held until maturity, which paid out (guessing here 2 % in interests) was simply worth a lot less when newly issued federal bonds promised 3-4 % interest with a lot shorter life span and shorter risk. So Silvergate, which had been too greedy when investing in these agency bonds, was forced to sell and realise a significant loss in the billions of US Dollars range. That was what brought down Silvergate. It was greed not "crypto-related events".

Good video, also, banks aren‚Äôt intermediaries. If they have $50 million in deposits and give a $10 million loan, they‚Äôre not taking the equivalent of $10 million out of everybody else‚Äôs savings, they are creating credit and a promissory note is issued. They are credit creators, not intermediaries, this is where so much stuff to do with banking goes wrong. They don‚Äôt lend money they have on the books, they create a credit out of thin air and make their money back on interest, which is also why is a source of inflation over time. And is why there is more credit in the system and actual hard-currency. This wouldn‚Äôt be the case in a system where banks are just intermediaries because every dollar would have a corresponding dollar. That‚Äôs not what we have.

I think Levine is half right - this particular problem and crypto's hypertrophic growth were enabled by QE and rates compression, but it's also a failure of small institutions to manage risk in a way that the wider market actually requires. If they want to remain viable while taking on big chunks of novel, synthetic, potentially illiquid, and mismatched liabilities they need to get in the game of managing for the unthinkable - in a big bank the trading desks or RM would be running sensitivity analysis on FFR rises right from the first JPow announcement - what would happen if rates rose 25-50-75bp-quarterly out to a 5% terminal rate, or 6% etc, or the Full Volcker. The desk would then have scenarios to hedge against, mainly interest rate swaps, which could also blow up but at least they have the capacity to engage in relatively sophisticated hedging. Smaller banks, no matter what their asset base looks like, if they're small they have a narrow and shallow pool of expertise and experience to run a difficult - but necessary - irs swaps program. In a very real sense complexity and market structure favor the big banks and funds, and small banks end up being the first penguin to toddle off the ice shelf, eaten by the hungriest seal waiting below.

Bank runs!  During the GFC, I worked at a small community bank.  In early-to-mid 2008, depositors that exceeded the FDIC limit, started to take their excess funds out of one local bank and put it into one or more other local banks.  They often had to wait for their CDs to mature.  The only thing this did was to keep those who opened new accounts VERY busy.  By mid-to-late 2008, things changed and people wanted to take cash home.  I was a lender, but I got up to five calls per day from customers wanted to get their hands on $5k to $50k and I would help as best I could.  Finally the FDIC raised the insurance limit and everything calmed down pretty quickly.  The problem with SVB was that 90% of its deposits were uninsured meaning that the average depositor at SVB had $2,500,000 on deposit, hence $250k insured and $2.25 million uninsured.  I predict a lot banks with large depositors will drop the interest paid on large accounts downward, while brokering CDs to smaller depositors.  It will hurt their net interest margin and profits, but will reduce the impact of bank runs.  That or the FDIC and/or Fed will "do something". What I have no idea, but the quicker the better.

Several banks are at risk not just this one. I'm not sure I completely buy this view.

1) After 2008, the fed demands that the banks increase their safe reserves.
2) The banks respond by creating new big portfolios of ultra-safe assets. Namely long-term US treasury bonds.
3) Nobody at the fed or the banks thinks at all about the impact of interest rates on those portfolios. Or the impact on actual bank liquidity with rising interest rates.
4) So now we have suddenly realized today that the "safe" long-term assets that represent reserves are incredibly ill-liquid in the face of rising interest rates and were never as safe as they seemed.

Big things have small beginnings. The last time all this happened was in the 1980s. It happened with mortgages and savings & loans in an environment of rising interest rates.

Unemployment and Inflation do work in opposition to each other GENERALLY. In the 1960s, we had inflation but wages actually outran it because of improved productivity had a deflationary push.
In other words, you had a strong wage increase that was pushing inflation up going against a general productivity gain that was pushing deflation. That is why the 1960s were the best economy for the middle class. Income outran expenses for the overwhelming majority of people.

Wage growth (caused by low unemployment) is not the only factor in the overall inflation rate. WAGE GROWTH currently is not anywhere near the rate of inflation but it is a small component of it.

IMF SDRs, that's the ticket. A basket of of currencies by weighted average %. Could be used for International Trade. With the advent of floating exchange rates, the IMF redefined the SDR as a weighted average of the U.S. dollar, the British pound, the Japanese yen, and the currencies that eventually comprised the euro. The dollar has the largest weight, currently about 40 percent, so changes in the dollar impact the SDRs more than similar changes in the pound, yen, or euro. Because of its construction, however, the SDR will likely be more stable relative to other currencies than the dollar; so, holding a portfolio of SDRs is liable to present a country with less exchange-rate valuation risk than holding dollars.

Alinsky advocated for empowering ordinary people to take collective action for social justice. He believed in building strong, localized organizations capable of challenging established authorities.Central to Alinsky's philosophy is the idea of power analysis ‚Äì understanding the sources of power and how to leverage them effectively for social change. Alinsky emphasized the use of nonviolent tactics in organizing, drawing inspiration from historical figures like Mahatma Gandhi. Alinsky encouraged organizers to be flexible and pragmatic, adapting their strategies based on the specific context and goals of their campaigns.
It's important to note that opinions on Saul Alinsky and his methods vary. Some view him as a pragmatic strategist for social change, while others criticize his tactics as too confrontational. Understanding Alinsky's ideas requires an exploration of his writings and their impact on community organizing.

Saul Alinsky was a prominent community organizer and writer, best known for his influential work "Rules for Radicals." Alinsky's approach to community organizing has left a lasting impact on grassroots movements.  This is their playbook.

US Interest Rates Hikes Are Emerging Into Weapons Of Mass Destruction For The World Economy: The Threat Of Global Recession In 2023

The US consumer price inflation report for August has crushed Americans‚Äô hopes that inflation would peak in the summer. But for practically everyone who doesn‚Äôt live in the country with the largest economy in the world, it‚Äôs going to be a double bummer. This is because the US Federal Reserve, led by Jerome Powell, will now feel empowered to raise interest rates even further to curb inflation.

Unfortunately, sometimes the problem is greater than the remedy. Parts of the global economy will collapse if the Fed does raise rates aggressively. The impacts will be felt beyond its national jurisdiction. The global recession will in turn have an impact on US economic growth. The world of unexpected repercussions will then suddenly become our focus

The trajectory of the two-year US Treasury yields, which are followed by international bond markets, is alarming for countries and currencies that are unable to keep up with the rates.
The yields were 0.2% at this time last year; they are now 19 times greater. And this is all before the Fed begins its aggressive $95 billion monthly quantitative tightening program. It truly hasn‚Äôt had time to evaluate the results of its brisk hiking. The dollar is the world‚Äôs reserve currency, like it or not. If cash dries up due to increased rates, everyone outside of the US will be affected.

The most recent Bank of America global survey of fund managers, released on Tuesday, reveals the largest underweight of global stocks in its history. You won‚Äôt run the risk of losing your job as an investment analyst if you solely use dollar-denominated assets or currencies. It‚Äôs hard to predict what will change this way of thinking.

When the dollar is getting stronger, other economies and markets have a very difficult time competing. As the Fed‚Äôs rapid interest rate increases force ever-faster flights to quality, that omnipotence is destroying many of the world‚Äôs currencies.

Imagine Japan. The yen has fallen more than 25% versus the dollar in the last year, to its lowest level since 1990. Due to the need to import the majority of its energy and pay for it in dollars, the nation‚Äôs export-led economic advantage over the US has crumbled.
The Bank of Japan has been compelled to strengthen its currency defence. Active intervention is now a real option, and it would likely be financed by selling its holdings of US Treasury notes.

The BOJ was the only major central bank for a considerable amount of time content to embrace inflation as a road to growth for its sluggish economy. Finally, prints above its 2% threshold are being seen. It also kept a tight hold on its bond market to keep interest rates low, and even negative.
It cannot, however, do either of these things and stop the downward trend of its currency. It can only allow the yen to fall so much or so quickly. And the Chinese yuan, Korean won, and Taiwan dollar will all suffer as a result. The BOJ‚Äôs approach might be destroyed, upsetting the rest of Asia, if the dollar experiences yet another period of strength fueled by a new rate hike from the Fed.
In the event of an unwelcome currency decline, China will feel justified in retaliating in kind. It usually strictly regulates it, but during the past six months, it has had to let the yuan lose more than 10% of its value against the dollar. Even the second-largest currency in the world is powerless against the American inflationary wave.

Since the spring of last year, the euro and the pound have been battling out for the lowest dollar value on the opposite side of Eurasia. Europe is already deprived by the amount of money spent to combat the pandemic, and because it relies on Russian natural gas, it is also now in the crosshairs of the energy crisis.
Growth is rapidly vanishing in front of our eyes as the UK has been stagnating all year and several countries in the European Union are entering a recession. According to economists at Deutsche Bank AG, the German economy could fall by as much as 4% in 2019.
Likewise to the Fed Reserve, the European Central Bank as well as the Bank of England predict parallel declines in the liquidity of the banking system, suspensions of asset acquisitions for money creation, and significant rate rises.

All that enter here, abandon hope.

We practically let the Fed set interest rates for the entire world, therefore this is what will happen. However, Fed Chair Powell and his countrymen are determined by myopia since all they can see is the oversaturated American labour market. The ensuing financial arms race runs the potential of being disastrous.
The fact is that not every economy needs to have ever-rising borrowing costs to stifle demand; a large part of global inflation is external and driven by supply-side factors.

And since COVID-19 struck in 2020 and severely slowed down globalization, the world has undergone a profound transformation. The response of the Fed and other central banks is unchanged, though.

Greater flexibility is needed to halt and restart the global economy than what the harsh mechanism of interest rates can provide. Weaning financial markets and asset prices away from continuous cycles of quantitative easing is a positive thing. The Fed has, yet, twice mishandled the unwinding procedure.
Why do central banks keep trying to hammer a 2 per cent inflation target pin into the head of massive economies when it is no longer desirable or viable to do so? Surely it‚Äôs time to move away from precise numbers and towards a flexible range. Although base effects would certainly cause headline inflation to fall significantly next year anyhow, bringing core inflation, which excludes food and energy, back to much lower levels will be extremely costly from an economic standpoint.
The US Fed‚Äôs efforts will eventually backfire on both the US and the Fed. By then, all of the pandemic‚Äôs trillions of dollars worth of stimulus work will have been undone‚Äîwhat a staggering waste of time, resources, and energy.

Interest rate hikes are putting the world economy in threat of entering a recession in 2023.

The US Federal Reserve Board will convene once more on September 20‚Äì21. There is a solid argument for the Federal to halt its unrelenting tightening of monetary policy, even if the majority of economists predict the next big hike in interest rates.
A spate of financial crises in emerging markets and developing countries, in addition to the recession, is also anticipated to do them ‚Äúpermanent harm,‚Äù the report stated. Compared to the period leading up to prior global recessions, the loss in worldwide consumer confidence has already been much more severe.
According to a World Bank analysis, major central banks around the world have been rising interest rates this year with an extent of coherence that has not been seen in the last 50 years, and this trend is likely to continue far into next year.

Paper money eventually returns to its intrinsic value ‚Äì zero (Everything you own is worthless)

At one point in time, money was backed by the tangible value of gold or other precious metals, legal tender for anything of equal value.
That is not the case any longer. The value of a dollar bill today is what the government says it is. This arbitrary value is dependent on the actions of the government. There are no limits to how much money a government can put into circulation.
That is because this money isn‚Äôt backed by any real value; it is ‚Äòfiat‚Äô currency.
What is Fiat Money?
Fiat money is a government-issued currency that is not backed by anything physical. The value of fiat money is based on supply and demand and the stability of the issuing government, rather than the worth of a commodity or other asset backing it.
While fiat money gives governments‚Äô central banks greater control over the economy because they control how much currency is printed, one danger of this is that governments will print too much of it, resulting in hyperinflation.
The problem with Fiat Currency.
Throughout time, attempts of using fiat currency, even today, have failed. When governments print money that isn‚Äôt backed by any value, disaster inevitably ensues. Paper currency has led to the collapse of many economies that have tried to institute a fiat currency to trade for goods and services, yet the long history of failed fiat currency is being ignored by today‚Äôs central banks and governments.
Because fiat money is not linked to physical reserves, it risks losing value due to inflation or even becoming worthless in the event of hyperinflation. When people lose faith in a nation‚Äôs currency, the money will no longer be of any value. That differs from currency backed by gold, for example; it has intrinsic value because of the demand for gold.
Since fiat money is not a scarce or fixed resource like gold, central banks have much greater control over its supply, which gives them the power to manage economic variables such as credit supply, liquidity and interest rates.
When governments began printing paper money these notes were considered to be as good as gold.
In theory, everyone who held this paper currency could go to a bank or financial institution and convert their currency into physical gold. This is what became known as the gold standard. Initially, the governments only printed as much currency as they had physical gold to back it up.
But soon they realised realized that the physical commodity backing the currency was tying them down from unbridled spending and also that a situation where everyone went to exchange their currency for gold would likely never happen. So, they began to print more paper money, thus creating the fractional banking system.
The manipulation of fiat money quickly resulted in the manipulation of fiat debt, benefitting a select few and ruining the rest.

The US dollar became fiat currency when it stopped being backed by gold over 46 years ago and it has lost 97 per cent of its value since the establishment of the Federal Reserve in 1913.
Examples of failed fiat currencies
China was the first country to use paper money in the 7th century.
This worked briefly since the paper could be traded for rare, valuable metals, such as gold and silver but as China entered into a costly war with Mongolia and in an effort at expansion started to flood paper money throughout the empire. As China‚Äôs trade grew, the influx of fiat paper ‚Äì currency backed by no value ‚Äì caused even the wealthiest to be ruined.
France has tried to implement, and been defeated, by fiat money three times.
King, Louis XIV, left his successor heavily in debt, who took the advice of the Scottish economist John Law and simply flooded the country with paper currency instead of the previously acceptable coins.
The paper money devalued the actually valuable coins, causing the heir to bankrupt his own country. Yet France didn‚Äôt learn its lesson the first time, more than 100 years later, France gave paper money another attempt, creating an inflationary spiral of 13,000 per cent. Napoleon, and the introduction of a gold-backed Franc, eventually settled the crisis.
Another country faced with unpayable debt was post-WWI Germany.
Germany did not learn from history. Instead, it created a state of unheard-of hyperinflation. A huge number of printing companies began printing out paper money as fast as they could, devaluing the German Mark so much that its only real value was to be used as kindling.
It seemed American might finally have learned a lesson. Up until 1913, American currency was strictly backed with actual gold.
The establishment of the Federal Reserve that year reduced the amount of gold officially backing the dollar and owning gold became illegal. In 1971, the gold standard was eliminated as the US dollar officially became another piece of paper. Its value has decreased by 92% since 1913.
Growing discontent in Venezuela, fuelled by hyperinflation has led to a political crisis.
The biggest problem facing modern-day Venezuelans in their day-to-day lives is hyperinflation.
By the end of last year, prices were doubling, on average, every 19 days. This has left many Venezuelans struggling to afford basic items such as food and toiletries.
Venezuela once boasted Latin America‚Äôs richest economy with one of the biggest oil reserves on the planet.
But under former president, Hugo Ch√°vez and current President Maduro, corruption, mismanagement and high levels of debt have resulted in the country‚Äôs economic collapse.
Venezuela‚Äôs economy is in shambles and the country was plunged into political chaos as a result of poor government decisions causing one of the most devastating circumstances of hyperinflation in recent times.
Ôøº
Argentina looking into the barrel of an economic crisis.
Argentina ended 2018 with the second-highest inflation figure in Latin America, behind Venezuela, as reported by the national statistics institute.
Argentina has been subject to two major currency crashes in 2018 that saw the peso lose 50 percent of its value against the dollar.
When President Macri took office at the end of 2015 the deficit in the government‚Äôs finances was large. He aimed to bring this down but adopted a gradual approach to economic reform.
For years, populist governments printed money to finance wide budget deficits, causing prices of consumer goods to spike. Macri‚Äôs government reduced that practice, but his hikes to utility prices as part of an effort to reduce subsidies and close the fiscal deficit have kept inflation high. The rapid drop in the exchange rate prompted inflation to accelerate in recent months.
In response to Argentina‚Äôs inflation surge, the Banco Central de la Rep√∫blica Argentina (BCRA) did what all central banks do and increased up interest rates in an attempt to keep the peso from plunging and generating more inflation.
These economic woes forced President Mauricio Macri to seek aid from the International Monetary Fund (IMF), securing a bailout loan of over $50 billion.

Usury and the collapse of empires

The American government recently played Russian roulette with its economy by threatening to default on its debt. Of course, nobody actually thought that the Americans would truly default at this time. After all, the Americans can quite literally print dollars to pay their debt. But it is also possible that the USA has entered a state of decline: massive public and private debts without growth quickly leads to collapse.
While it is a clich√©, I am fascinated by the analogy between the American superpower and the fall of the Roman Empire. The economics of the Roman Empire during its decline bear some similarity to our current situation.
Rome partially moved away from a gold-based currency some time during its decline. It started to mint coins with less gold content. Similarly, the Americans switched to a fiat currency in the seventies under Nixon. The American government no longer guarantees a gold equivalent for the American dollar. In both cases, the currency became backed by the great economical and military power of the government. Unfortunately, this type of backing loses its efficiency when a decline is hinted. Your dollars are only valuable if you think that the USA will keep growing stronger. If you think that the American economy might suffer on the long term, then American dollars are much less interesting. Thus, predictions of decline become self-fulfilling.
During the fall of the Roman Empire, many citizens were enticed to borrow from the super wealthy. Eventually, the peasant class was wiped out: they became serfs. Serfs live in conditions where they cannot possibly expect to improve their conditions. They constantly owe more than they earn. They are, effectively, slaves.
The Catholic Church, which emerged at the time, correspondingly considered usury to be a sin. While it seems that the stance of the Catholic Church on usury is quite a bit more flexible today, religions like Islam still forbid usury. Judaism only allows usury toward non-Jews.
What is usury? Lending money knowing that it will make people poorer. Correspondingly, most consumer debt is usury. It is a transfer of wealth from the poor to the rich which makes us, overall, poorer. Lending money to Greece at this time is also usury.
Could the religious stance against usury be wise?
Economists who expect people to be rational won‚Äôt believe in usury. Surely, people borrow money to be better off. Yet the average credit card debt per household is over $15,000 in the USA (and it grows all the time, of course). Does anyone believe that these $15,000 are invested in highly profitable ventures? (They would need to be highly profitable since credit cards often charge over 15% for loans.)

What is global debt?
END OF DAYS AND LAWLESSNESS

Global debt is borrowing by governments, businesses and people, and it‚Äôs at dangerously high levels.

In 2021, global debt reached a record $303 trillion, according to the Institute of International Finance, a global financial industry association.

This is a further jump from record global debt in 2020 of $226 trillion, as reported by the IMF in its Global Debt Database. This was the biggest one-year debt surge since the Second World War, according to the IMF.

COVID-19 caused high spending on measures to protect jobs, lives and livelihoods. ‚ÄúNow the war in Ukraine is adding risks to unprecedented levels of public borrowing,‚Äù the IMF warns in a blog.

The current debt wave is the world‚Äôs fourth since 1970, the World Bank says.

Why does global debt matter?

Emerging and developing economies have been the worst hit by previous debt crises, World Bank research shows.

To meet debt payments, at least 100 countries will have to reduce spending on health, education and social protection, the IMF estimates.

If countries default on their debts, it can cause panic on financial markets and economic slowdowns.

For businesses, meeting repayments on high levels of debt can mean less money is available to invest in jobs and expansion. Insolvency is also a risk for businesses that are unable to pay back their loans.

For households, high levels of debt can force them to cut some areas of spending, such as food or fuel. Low-income households are most at risk, the IMF says.

What do experts say about global debt?

When low-income countries get into debt distress, it‚Äôs associated with ‚Äúprotracted recessions, high inflation and fewer resources going to essential sectors like health, education and social safety nets, with a disproportionate impact on the poor‚Äù, the World Bank says.

Debt distress is when a country is unable to fulfil its financial obligations, such as repayments due on its debt. The IMF and World Bank believe 60% of low-income countries are at or near this point.

At a time when the war in Ukraine is disrupting food supplies and pushing food prices higher, countries that ‚Äústrain to pay their creditors will also struggle to help their poorest citizens‚Äù, Al Jazeera reports.

As food and fuel prices soar, governments may need to give more grants to households in need to help them cover costs, particularly in low-income countries, the IMF says.

In 2021, the countries with the highest global debt levels compared to GDP were Japan (257%), Sudan (210%), Greece (207%), Eritrea (175%) and Cape Verde (161%), according to data published by Visual Capitalist.

Rising prices mean inflation is spiking, so central banks are increasing interest rates to try and contain this. Rising interest rates, in turn, mean higher loan repayments.

The most highly indebted governments, households and firms will be hardest hit by significant interest rate rises, so countries have to be careful to strike the ‚Äúright balance‚Äù, the IMF warns.

Paper money eventually returns to its intrinsic value ‚Äì zero (Everything you own is worthless)

At one point in time, money was backed by the tangible value of gold or other precious metals, legal tender for anything of equal value.
That is not the case any longer. The value of a dollar bill today is what the government says it is. This arbitrary value is dependent on the actions of the government. There are no limits to how much money a government can put into circulation.
That is because this money isn‚Äôt backed by any real value; it is ‚Äòfiat‚Äô currency.
What is Fiat Money?
Fiat money is a government-issued currency that is not backed by anything physical. The value of fiat money is based on supply and demand and the stability of the issuing government, rather than the worth of a commodity or other asset backing it.
While fiat money gives governments‚Äô central banks greater control over the economy because they control how much currency is printed, one danger of this is that governments will print too much of it, resulting in hyperinflation.
The problem with Fiat Currency.
Throughout time, attempts of using fiat currency, even today, have failed. When governments print money that isn‚Äôt backed by any value, disaster inevitably ensues. Paper currency has led to the collapse of many economies that have tried to institute a fiat currency to trade for goods and services, yet the long history of failed fiat currency is being ignored by today‚Äôs central banks and governments.
Because fiat money is not linked to physical reserves, it risks losing value due to inflation or even becoming worthless in the event of hyperinflation. When people lose faith in a nation‚Äôs currency, the money will no longer be of any value. That differs from currency backed by gold, for example; it has intrinsic value because of the demand for gold.

DEPT: THE END GAME
The Great Inflation was the defining macroeconomic event of the second half of the twentieth century. Over the nearly two decades it lasted, the global monetary system established during World War II was abandoned, there were four economic recessions, two severe energy shortages, and the unprecedented peacetime implementation of wage and price controls. It was, according to one prominent economist, ‚Äúthe greatest failure of American macroeconomic policy in the postwar period‚Äù (Siegel 1994).
But that failure also brought a transformative change in macroeconomic theory and, ultimately, the rules that today guide the monetary policies of the Federal Reserve and other central banks around the world. If the Great Inflation was a consequence of a great failure of American macroeconomic policy, its conquest should be counted as a triumph.

Forensics of the Great Inflation

In 1964, inflation measured a little more than 1 percent per year. It had been in this vicinity over the preceding six years. Inflation began ratcheting upward in the mid-1960s and reached more than 14 percent in 1980. It eventually declined to average only 3.5 percent in the latter half of the 1980s.
While economists debate the relative importance of the factors that motivated and perpetuated inflation for more than a decade, there is little debate about its source. The origins of the Great Inflation were policies that allowed for an excessive growth in the supply of money‚ÄîFederal Reserve policies.

Monetary policy lives in the shadow of debt. US federal debt held by the public was about 25 percent of GDP in 1980, when Federal Reserve chair Paul Volcker started raising rates to tame inflation. Now, it is 100 percent of GDP and rising quickly, with no end in sight. When the Fed raises interest rates 1 percentage point, it raises the interest costs on debt by 1 percentage point, and, at 100 percent debt to GDP, 1 percent of GDP is about $227 billion. A 7.5 percent interest rate therefore creates interest costs of 7.5 percent of GDP, or $1.7 trillion.
Where will those trillions of dollars come from? Congress could drastically cut spending or find ways to increase tax revenues. Alternatively, the US Treasury could try to borrow additional trillions. But for that option to work, bond buyers must be convinced that a future Congress will cut spending or raise tax revenues by the same trillions of dollars, plus interest. Even if investors seem confident at the moment, we cannot assume that they will remain so indefinitely, especially if additional borrowing serves only to pay higher interest on existing debt. Even for the United States, there is a point at which bond investors see the end coming and demand even higher interest rates as a risk premium, thereby raising debt costs even more, in a spiral that leads to a debt crisis or to a sharp and uncontrollable surge of inflation. If the US government could borrow arbitrary amounts and never worry about repayment, it could send its citizens checks forever and nobody would have to work or pay taxes again. Alas, we do not live in that fanciful world.
In sum, for higher interest rates to reduce inflation, they must be accompanied by credible and persistent fiscal tightening, now or later. If the fiscal tightening does not come, higher interest rates will eventually fail to contain inflation.
This is a perfectly standard proposition, though it is often overlooked when discussing the US and Europe. It is embodied in the models used by the US Fed and other central banks. It was standard International Monetary Fund advice for decades.
Successful inflation and currency stabilization almost always includes monetary and fiscal reform, and usually microeconomic reform. The role of fiscal and microeconomic reform is to generate sustainably higher tax revenues by boosting economic growth and broadening the tax base, rather than with sharply higher and growth-reducing marginal tax rates. Many attempts at monetary stabilization have fallen apart because the fiscal or microeconomic reforms failed. Latin American economic history is full of such episodes.

However, I heard one online expert explain that new funds won‚Äôt be available to banks, but it will take up to a year for the ‚Äúbuyback‚Äù process to complete‚Ä¶. where banks buy back the toxic (low interest mortgage backed) loans and finally have to quantify the anticipated loss on those loans. As the buyback takes place and banks book the losses (because they are paying higher rates to keep deposits from moving to Tbills vs what the long term mortgage securities are generating) ‚Ä¶ the bank liquidity will be more accurately quantified and will be considerably lower than what is showing on their financial statements today. In an effort to prevent resistance to central bank digital currencies in particular and to digitalization of financial transactions in general, the central banks have sworn that such digital accounts will be replacements for cash that are fully under the control of the account owners. If the central banks and the governments they serve see that bank runs are starting, they will renege on those promises and either 1) electronically limit withdrawals; and/or 2) electronically block withdrawals completely (bank holidays) for periods of time. Those withdrawal restrictions will be much easier to impose electronically. Similarly, the central banks will find it much easier to selectively electronically inject extra liquidity into the banks that are under the greatest pressure. Those rapid, selective, and proportional counter-cyclical monetary measures are among the primary reasons most of the major central banks are gearing up their wholesale and retail CBDCs. Whether those new powers are good or bad can be and will be hotly debated.

#19:30 - No Patrik, the crash of Silvergate was not caused by crypto-related events. I know you hate crypto and millenials living in the moms basements, but please keep to the truth.

Silvergate crashed because of good, old-fashioned greed. Silvergate had, as you said at #14:30 invested a lot of their customers deposits in these hold-to-maturity bonds, these "agency bonds": bonds that mature some 4-5 years into the future.

Investopedia (which I choose to trust on this matter - your mileage may wary) describes these agency bonds as follows:

- "An agency bond is a security issued by a government-sponsored enterprise or by a federal government department other than the U.S. Treasury. Some are not fully guaranteed in the same way that U.S. Treasury and municipal bonds are.
[...]
Treasury bonds are attractive to investors because of their safety, liquidity, and state tax- exempt interest. Agency bonds are attractive to investors because of the safety, liquidity, higher yields relative to Treasuries, and for some agencies, their state tax-exempt interest."

The problem with these hold-to-maturity bonds is that when Silvergate bought them at "fair value" just a few years or months ago, the US interest rate was much lower than today. And bond values correlates inverse to interest rate, so now with the current and continuing FED raises of interests, the value of these fixed interest bonds goes down.

Now, as all of us "knows" you really haven't lost money in the stock market until you sell your bad performing stonks. Same with Silvergate. On their accounting books, these agency bonds was reported and valued at their original price, not their new fair value taking the current interest rate into account. It was only when Silvergate customers started to withdraw deposits and Silvergate needed good old fashioned fiat US Dollars to keep up with the withdrawals, the problem with the original fair value not being fair any longer became a problem. The agency bonds, held until maturity, which paid out (guessing here 2 % in interests) was simply worth a lot less when newly issued federal bonds promised 3-4 % interest with a lot shorter life span and shorter risk. So Silvergate, which had been too greedy when investing in these agency bonds, was forced to sell and realise a significant loss in the billions of US Dollars range. That was what brought down Silvergate. It was greed not "crypto-related events".

Good video, also, banks aren‚Äôt intermediaries. If they have $50 million in deposits and give a $10 million loan, they‚Äôre not taking the equivalent of $10 million out of everybody else‚Äôs savings, they are creating credit and a promissory note is issued. They are credit creators, not intermediaries, this is where so much stuff to do with banking goes wrong. They don‚Äôt lend money they have on the books, they create a credit out of thin air and make their money back on interest, which is also why is a source of inflation over time. And is why there is more credit in the system and actual hard-currency. This wouldn‚Äôt be the case in a system where banks are just intermediaries because every dollar would have a corresponding dollar. That‚Äôs not what we have.

I think Levine is half right - this particular problem and crypto's hypertrophic growth were enabled by QE and rates compression, but it's also a failure of small institutions to manage risk in a way that the wider market actually requires. If they want to remain viable while taking on big chunks of novel, synthetic, potentially illiquid, and mismatched liabilities they need to get in the game of managing for the unthinkable - in a big bank the trading desks or RM would be running sensitivity analysis on FFR rises right from the first JPow announcement - what would happen if rates rose 25-50-75bp-quarterly out to a 5% terminal rate, or 6% etc, or the Full Volcker. The desk would then have scenarios to hedge against, mainly interest rate swaps, which could also blow up but at least they have the capacity to engage in relatively sophisticated hedging. Smaller banks, no matter what their asset base looks like, if they're small they have a narrow and shallow pool of expertise and experience to run a difficult - but necessary - irs swaps program. In a very real sense complexity and market structure favor the big banks and funds, and small banks end up being the first penguin to toddle off the ice shelf, eaten by the hungriest seal waiting below.

Bank runs!  During the GFC, I worked at a small community bank.  In early-to-mid 2008, depositors that exceeded the FDIC limit, started to take their excess funds out of one local bank and put it into one or more other local banks.  They often had to wait for their CDs to mature.  The only thing this did was to keep those who opened new accounts VERY busy.  By mid-to-late 2008, things changed and people wanted to take cash home.  I was a lender, but I got up to five calls per day from customers wanted to get their hands on $5k to $50k and I would help as best I could.  Finally the FDIC raised the insurance limit and everything calmed down pretty quickly.  The problem with SVB was that 90% of its deposits were uninsured meaning that the average depositor at SVB had $2,500,000 on deposit, hence $250k insured and $2.25 million uninsured.  I predict a lot banks with large depositors will drop the interest paid on large accounts downward, while brokering CDs to smaller depositors.  It will hurt their net interest margin and profits, but will reduce the impact of bank runs.  That or the FDIC and/or Fed will "do something". What I have no idea, but the quicker the better.

Several banks are at risk not just this one. I'm not sure I completely buy this view.

1) After 2008, the fed demands that the banks increase their safe reserves.
2) The banks respond by creating new big portfolios of ultra-safe assets. Namely long-term US treasury bonds.
3) Nobody at the fed or the banks thinks at all about the impact of interest rates on those portfolios. Or the impact on actual bank liquidity with rising interest rates.
4) So now we have suddenly realized today that the "safe" long-term assets that represent reserves are incredibly ill-liquid in the face of rising interest rates and were never as safe as they seemed.

Big things have small beginnings. The last time all this happened was in the 1980s. It happened with mortgages and savings & loans in an environment of rising interest rates.

Some banks are too big to fail, and they will be rescued no matter what. This is because if the total banking system fails, the economy crashes 100%, and the politicians will not let that happen. If you have a deposit OVER the insured limit per bank, then I would diversify into many large banks, and not least trasury bonds with short maturity. If interes rates go up, you get an unrealized loss, but if you sit to maturity you get the deposit + interest, but if rates go DOWN, you get an unrealized gain, which you can realize selling the bond in the market. The odds are big that the FED will have to decrease the short term FED rates if /when we get a financial crisis, to restart the economy. Win win. @Michael....bank deposits going down. This doesn't mean that the bank run has started. Specially in the high interest rate environment.

Think of it this way. The currency has always go to the bank. If u pull out of the bank. U will pull out of bank A and put it in bank B or C. Even if the rich guys pull out of a bank X, they will eventually be putting it in bank Y or Z. So on an overall basis, the deposits in bank A goes down but the deposits in bank B and C go up. Because the currency has to go somewhere. U won't put it under the matrice.

In another scenarios. It can mean that the currency is being pulled out of country X and the deposits in the banks in country Y are going up. That would be capital flight. And a more likely scenario.

The last possibility is that the central bank is pulling the liquidity out. I.e. shrinking the currency supply. So a bank deposit decrease has to be seen with deflation in the currency supply in that country.
